OS commanding vulnerability

HIGH

Summary

OS Commanding was found at: "http://localhost/VulnerableApp/CommandInjection/LEVEL_4", using HTTP method GET. The sent data was: "ipaddress=%0D%0A%2Fbin%2Fcat%20%2Fetc%2Fpasswd" The modified parameter was "ipaddress". This vulnerability was found in the request with id 4501.


Description

To perform specific actions from within a web application, it is occasionally required to run Operating System commands and have the output of these commands captured by the web application and returned to the client.

OS command injection occurs when user supplied input is inserted into one of these commands without proper sanitisation and is then executed by the server.

Cyber-criminals will abuse this weakness to perform their own arbitrary commands on the server. This can include everything from simple ping commands to map the internal network, to obtaining full control of the server.

It was possible to inject and verify the execution of specific Operating System commands which indicates that proper input sanitisation is not occurring.

  • Vulnerable URL: http://localhost/VulnerableApp/CommandInjection/LEVEL_4
  • Vulnerable Parameter: ipaddress

Fix

It is recommended that untrusted data is never used to form a command to be executed by the OS.

To validate data, the application should ensure that the supplied value contains only the characters that are required to perform the required action.

For example, where the form field expects an IP address, only numbers and periods should be accepted. Additionally, all control operators (&, &&, |, ||, $, \, #) should be explicitly denied and never accepted as valid input by the server.

References

  • WASC
  • OWASP

HTTP proof

GET http://localhost/VulnerableApp/CommandInjection/LEVEL_4?ipaddress=%0D%0A%2Fbin%2Fcat%20%2Fetc%2Fpasswd HTTP/1.1
User-agent: python-requests/2.31.0
Host: localhost
Accept-encoding: gzip, deflate
Accept: */*
Connection: keep-alive
b'HTTP/1.1 200 \r\nServer: openresty/1.21.4.3\r\nDate: Wed, 20 Mar 2024 19:25:22 GMT\r\nContent-Type: application/json\r\nTransfer-Encoding: chunked\r\nConnection: keep-alive\r\n'
b'{"content":"ping: bad address \'\\n\'\\nroot:x:0:0:root:/root:/bin/ash\\nbin:x:1:1:bin:/bin:/sbin/nologin\\ndaemon:x:2:2:daemon:/sbin:/sbin/nologin\\nadm:x:3:4:adm:/var/adm:/sbin/nologin\\nlp:x:4:7:lp:/var/spool/lpd:/sbin/nologin\\nsync:x:5:0:sync:/sbin:/bin/sync\\nshutdown:x:6:0:shutdown:/sbin:/sbin/shutdown\\nhalt:x:7:0:halt:/sbin:/sbin/halt\\nmail:x:8:12:mail:/var/spool/mail:/sbin/nologin\\nnews:x:9:13:news:/usr/lib/news:/sbin/nologin\\nuucp:x:10:14:uucp:/var/spool/uucppublic:/sbin/nologin\\noperator:x:11:0:operator:/root:/bin/sh\\nman:x:13:15:man:/usr/man:/sbin/nologin\\npostmaster:x:14:12:postmaster:/var/spool/mail:/sbin/nologin\\ncron:x:16:16:cron:/var/spool/cron:/sbin/nologin\\nftp:x:21:21::/var/lib/ftp:/sbin/nologin\\nsshd:x:22:22:sshd:/dev/null:/sbin/nologin\\nat:x:25:25:at:/var/spool/cron/atjobs:/sbin/nologin\\nsquid:x:31:31:Squid:/var/cache/squid:/sbin/nologin\\nxfs:x:33:33:X Font Server:/etc/X11/fs:/sbin/nologin\\ngames:x:35:35:games:/usr/games:/sbin/nologin\\npostgres:x:70:70::/var/lib/postgresql:/bin/sh\\ncyrus:x:85:12::/usr/cyrus:/sbin/nologin\\nvpopmail:x:89:89::/var/vpopmail:/sbin/nologin\\nntp:x:123:123:NTP:/var/empty:/sbin/nologin\\nsmmsp:x:209:209:smmsp:/var/spool/mqueue:/sbin/nologin\\nguest:x:405:100:guest:/dev/null:/sbin/nologin\\nnobody:x:65534:65534:nobody:/:/sbin/nologin\\n","isValid":true}'

SQL injection

HIGH

Summary

SQL injection in a Unknown database was found at: "http://localhost/VulnerableApp/CommandInjection/LEVEL_4", using HTTP method GET. The sent data was: "ipaddress=a%27b%22c%27d%22" The modified parameter was "ipaddress". This vulnerability was found in the request with id 4624.


Description

Due to the requirement for dynamic content of today's web applications, many rely on a database backend to store data that will be called upon and processed by the web application (or other programs). Web applications retrieve data from the database by using Structured Query Language (SQL) queries.

To meet demands of many developers, database servers (such as MSSQL, MySQL, Oracle etc.) have additional built-in functionality that can allow extensive control of the database and interaction with the host operating system itself. An SQL injection occurs when a value originating from the client's request is used within a SQL query without prior sanitisation. This could allow cyber-criminals to execute arbitrary SQL code and steal data or use the additional functionality of the database server to take control of more server components.

The successful exploitation of a SQL injection can be devastating to an organisation and is one of the most commonly exploited web application vulnerabilities.

This injection was detected as the tool was able to cause the server to respond to the request with a database related error.

  • Vulnerable URL: http://localhost/VulnerableApp/CommandInjection/LEVEL_4
  • Vulnerable Parameter: ipaddress

Fix

The only proven method to prevent against SQL injection attacks while still maintaining full application functionality is to use parameterized queries (also known as prepared statements). When utilising this method of querying the database, any value supplied by the client will be handled as a string value rather than part of the SQL query.

Additionally, when utilising parameterized queries, the database engine will automatically check to make sure the string being used matches that of the column. For example, the database engine will check that the user supplied input is an integer if the database column is configured to contain integers.

References

  • SecuriTeam
  • Wikipedia
  • OWASP
  • WASC
  • W3 Schools
  • UnixWiz

HTTP proof

GET http://localhost/VulnerableApp/CommandInjection/LEVEL_4?ipaddress=a%27b%22c%27d%22 HTTP/1.1
User-agent: python-requests/2.31.0
Host: localhost
Accept-encoding: gzip, deflate
Accept: */*
Connection: keep-alive
b'HTTP/1.1 200 \r\nServer: openresty/1.21.4.3\r\nDate: Wed, 20 Mar 2024 19:25:27 GMT\r\nContent-Type: application/json\r\nTransfer-Encoding: chunked\r\nConnection: keep-alive\r\n'
b'{"content":"sh: syntax error: unterminated quoted string\\n","isValid":true}'

OS commanding vulnerability

HIGH

Summary

OS Commanding was found at: "http://localhost/VulnerableApp/CommandInjection/LEVEL_5", using HTTP method GET. The sent data was: "ipaddress=%0D%0A%2Fbin%2Fcat%20%2Fetc%2Fpasswd" The modified parameter was "ipaddress". This vulnerability was found in the request with id 4735.


Description

To perform specific actions from within a web application, it is occasionally required to run Operating System commands and have the output of these commands captured by the web application and returned to the client.

OS command injection occurs when user supplied input is inserted into one of these commands without proper sanitisation and is then executed by the server.

Cyber-criminals will abuse this weakness to perform their own arbitrary commands on the server. This can include everything from simple ping commands to map the internal network, to obtaining full control of the server.

It was possible to inject and verify the execution of specific Operating System commands which indicates that proper input sanitisation is not occurring.

  • Vulnerable URL: http://localhost/VulnerableApp/CommandInjection/LEVEL_5
  • Vulnerable Parameter: ipaddress

Fix

It is recommended that untrusted data is never used to form a command to be executed by the OS.

To validate data, the application should ensure that the supplied value contains only the characters that are required to perform the required action.

For example, where the form field expects an IP address, only numbers and periods should be accepted. Additionally, all control operators (&, &&, |, ||, $, \, #) should be explicitly denied and never accepted as valid input by the server.

References

  • WASC
  • OWASP

HTTP proof

GET http://localhost/VulnerableApp/CommandInjection/LEVEL_5?ipaddress=%0D%0A%2Fbin%2Fcat%20%2Fetc%2Fpasswd HTTP/1.1
User-agent: python-requests/2.31.0
Host: localhost
Accept-encoding: gzip, deflate
Accept: */*
Connection: keep-alive
b'HTTP/1.1 200 \r\nServer: openresty/1.21.4.3\r\nDate: Wed, 20 Mar 2024 19:25:31 GMT\r\nContent-Type: application/json\r\nTransfer-Encoding: chunked\r\nConnection: keep-alive\r\n'
b'{"content":"ping: bad address \'\\n\'\\nroot:x:0:0:root:/root:/bin/ash\\nbin:x:1:1:bin:/bin:/sbin/nologin\\ndaemon:x:2:2:daemon:/sbin:/sbin/nologin\\nadm:x:3:4:adm:/var/adm:/sbin/nologin\\nlp:x:4:7:lp:/var/spool/lpd:/sbin/nologin\\nsync:x:5:0:sync:/sbin:/bin/sync\\nshutdown:x:6:0:shutdown:/sbin:/sbin/shutdown\\nhalt:x:7:0:halt:/sbin:/sbin/halt\\nmail:x:8:12:mail:/var/spool/mail:/sbin/nologin\\nnews:x:9:13:news:/usr/lib/news:/sbin/nologin\\nuucp:x:10:14:uucp:/var/spool/uucppublic:/sbin/nologin\\noperator:x:11:0:operator:/root:/bin/sh\\nman:x:13:15:man:/usr/man:/sbin/nologin\\npostmaster:x:14:12:postmaster:/var/spool/mail:/sbin/nologin\\ncron:x:16:16:cron:/var/spool/cron:/sbin/nologin\\nftp:x:21:21::/var/lib/ftp:/sbin/nologin\\nsshd:x:22:22:sshd:/dev/null:/sbin/nologin\\nat:x:25:25:at:/var/spool/cron/atjobs:/sbin/nologin\\nsquid:x:31:31:Squid:/var/cache/squid:/sbin/nologin\\nxfs:x:33:33:X Font Server:/etc/X11/fs:/sbin/nologin\\ngames:x:35:35:games:/usr/games:/sbin/nologin\\npostgres:x:70:70::/var/lib/postgresql:/bin/sh\\ncyrus:x:85:12::/usr/cyrus:/sbin/nologin\\nvpopmail:x:89:89::/var/vpopmail:/sbin/nologin\\nntp:x:123:123:NTP:/var/empty:/sbin/nologin\\nsmmsp:x:209:209:smmsp:/var/spool/mqueue:/sbin/nologin\\nguest:x:405:100:guest:/dev/null:/sbin/nologin\\nnobody:x:65534:65534:nobody:/:/sbin/nologin\\n","isValid":true}'

SQL injection

HIGH

Summary

SQL injection in a Unknown database was found at: "http://localhost/VulnerableApp/CommandInjection/LEVEL_5", using HTTP method GET. The sent data was: "ipaddress=1%272%223" The modified parameter was "ipaddress". This vulnerability was found in the request with id 4804.


Description

Due to the requirement for dynamic content of today's web applications, many rely on a database backend to store data that will be called upon and processed by the web application (or other programs). Web applications retrieve data from the database by using Structured Query Language (SQL) queries.

To meet demands of many developers, database servers (such as MSSQL, MySQL, Oracle etc.) have additional built-in functionality that can allow extensive control of the database and interaction with the host operating system itself. An SQL injection occurs when a value originating from the client's request is used within a SQL query without prior sanitisation. This could allow cyber-criminals to execute arbitrary SQL code and steal data or use the additional functionality of the database server to take control of more server components.

The successful exploitation of a SQL injection can be devastating to an organisation and is one of the most commonly exploited web application vulnerabilities.

This injection was detected as the tool was able to cause the server to respond to the request with a database related error.

  • Vulnerable URL: http://localhost/VulnerableApp/CommandInjection/LEVEL_5
  • Vulnerable Parameter: ipaddress

Fix

The only proven method to prevent against SQL injection attacks while still maintaining full application functionality is to use parameterized queries (also known as prepared statements). When utilising this method of querying the database, any value supplied by the client will be handled as a string value rather than part of the SQL query.

Additionally, when utilising parameterized queries, the database engine will automatically check to make sure the string being used matches that of the column. For example, the database engine will check that the user supplied input is an integer if the database column is configured to contain integers.

References

  • SecuriTeam
  • Wikipedia
  • OWASP
  • WASC
  • W3 Schools
  • UnixWiz

HTTP proof

GET http://localhost/VulnerableApp/CommandInjection/LEVEL_5?ipaddress=1%272%223 HTTP/1.1
User-agent: python-requests/2.31.0
Host: localhost
Accept-encoding: gzip, deflate
Accept: */*
Connection: keep-alive
b'HTTP/1.1 200 \r\nServer: openresty/1.21.4.3\r\nDate: Wed, 20 Mar 2024 19:25:33 GMT\r\nContent-Type: application/json\r\nTransfer-Encoding: chunked\r\nConnection: keep-alive\r\n'
b'{"content":"sh: syntax error: unterminated quoted string\\n","isValid":true}'

Cross site scripting vulnerability

MEDIUM

Summary

A Cross Site Scripting vulnerability was found at: "http://localhost/VulnerableApp/ErrorBasedSQLInjectionVulnerability/LEVEL_1", using HTTP method GET. The sent data was: "id=" The modified parameter was "id". This vulnerability was found in the request with id 5206.


Description

Client-side scripts are used extensively by modern web applications. They perform from simple functions (such as the formatting of text) up to full manipulation of client-side data and Operating System interaction.

Cross Site Scripting (XSS) allows clients to inject arbitrary scripting code into a request and have the server return the script to the client in the response. This occurs because the application is taking untrusted data (in this example, from the client) and reusing it without performing any validation or encoding.

  • Vulnerable URL: http://localhost/VulnerableApp/ErrorBasedSQLInjectionVulnerability/LEVEL_1
  • Vulnerable Parameter: id

Fix

To remedy XSS vulnerabilities, it is important to never use untrusted or unfiltered data within the code of a HTML page.

Untrusted data can originate not only form the client but potentially a third party or previously uploaded file etc. Filtering of untrusted data typically involves converting special characters to their HTML entity encoded counterparts (however, other methods do exist, see references). These special characters include:

  • &
  • <
  • >
  • "
  • '
  • /

An example of HTML entity encoding is converting < to &lt;. Although it is possible to filter untrusted input, there are five locations within an HTML page where untrusted input (even if it has been filtered) should never be placed:

  1. Directly in a script.
  2. Inside an HTML comment.
  3. In an attribute name.
  4. In a tag name.
  5. Directly in CSS.

Each of these locations have their own form of escaping and filtering.

Because many browsers attempt to implement XSS protection, any manual verification of this finding should be conducted using multiple different browsers and browser versions.

References

  • WASC
  • Secunia
  • OWASP

HTTP proof

GET http://localhost/VulnerableApp/ErrorBasedSQLInjectionVulnerability/LEVEL_1?id=khrzr%3Ckhrzrkhrzr--%3Ekhrzrkhrzr%2A%2Fkhrzrkhrzr%2A%2F%3A%28%22%27khrzrkhrzr%3Akhrzrkhrzr%0Akhrzrkhrzr%22khrzrkhrzr%27khrzrkhrzr%60khrzrkhrzr%20%3Dkhrzr HTTP/1.1
User-agent: python-requests/2.31.0
Host: localhost
Accept-encoding: gzip, deflate
Accept: */*
Connection: keep-alive
b'HTTP/1.1 200 \r\nServer: openresty/1.21.4.3\r\nDate: Wed, 20 Mar 2024 19:25:43 GMT\r\nContent-Type: text/plain;charset=UTF-8\r\nContent-Length: 634\r\nConnection: keep-alive\r\n'
b'{ "isCarPresent": false, "moreInfo": StatementCallback; bad SQL grammar [select * from cars where id=khrzr<khrzrkhrzr-->khrzrkhrzr*/khrzrkhrzr*/:("\'khrzrkhrzr:khrzrkhrzr\nkhrzrkhrzr"khrzrkhrzr\'khrzrkhrzr`khrzrkhrzr =khrzr]; nested exception is org.h2.jdbc.JdbcSQLException: Syntax error in SQL statement "select * from cars where id=khrzr<khrzrkhrzr-->khrzrkhrzr*/khrzrkhrzr*/:(""\'khrzrkhrzr:khrzrkhrzr\nkhrzrkhrzr[*]""khrzrkhrzr\'khrzrkhrzr`khrzrkhrzr =khrzr"; SQL statement:\nselect * from cars where id=khrzr<khrzrkhrzr-->khrzrkhrzr*/khrzrkhrzr*/:("\'khrzrkhrzr:khrzrkhrzr\nkhrzrkhrzr"khrzrkhrzr\'khrzrkhrzr`khrzrkhrzr =khrzr [42000-176]}'

Cross site scripting vulnerability

MEDIUM

Summary

A Cross Site Scripting vulnerability was found at: "http://localhost/VulnerableApp/ErrorBasedSQLInjectionVulnerability/LEVEL_2", using HTTP method GET. The sent data was: "id=" The modified parameter was "id". This vulnerability was found in the request with id 5448.


Description

Client-side scripts are used extensively by modern web applications. They perform from simple functions (such as the formatting of text) up to full manipulation of client-side data and Operating System interaction.

Cross Site Scripting (XSS) allows clients to inject arbitrary scripting code into a request and have the server return the script to the client in the response. This occurs because the application is taking untrusted data (in this example, from the client) and reusing it without performing any validation or encoding.

  • Vulnerable URL: http://localhost/VulnerableApp/ErrorBasedSQLInjectionVulnerability/LEVEL_2
  • Vulnerable Parameter: id

Fix

To remedy XSS vulnerabilities, it is important to never use untrusted or unfiltered data within the code of a HTML page.

Untrusted data can originate not only form the client but potentially a third party or previously uploaded file etc. Filtering of untrusted data typically involves converting special characters to their HTML entity encoded counterparts (however, other methods do exist, see references). These special characters include:

  • &
  • <
  • >
  • "
  • '
  • /

An example of HTML entity encoding is converting < to &lt;. Although it is possible to filter untrusted input, there are five locations within an HTML page where untrusted input (even if it has been filtered) should never be placed:

  1. Directly in a script.
  2. Inside an HTML comment.
  3. In an attribute name.
  4. In a tag name.
  5. Directly in CSS.

Each of these locations have their own form of escaping and filtering.

Because many browsers attempt to implement XSS protection, any manual verification of this finding should be conducted using multiple different browsers and browser versions.

References

  • WASC
  • Secunia
  • OWASP

HTTP proof

GET http://localhost/VulnerableApp/ErrorBasedSQLInjectionVulnerability/LEVEL_2?id=lwutw%3Clwutwlwutw--%3Elwutwlwutw%2A%2Flwutwlwutw%2A%2F%3A%28%22%27lwutwlwutw%3Alwutwlwutw%0Alwutwlwutw%22lwutwlwutw%27lwutwlwutw%60lwutwlwutw%20%3Dlwutw HTTP/1.1
User-agent: python-requests/2.31.0
Host: localhost
Accept-encoding: gzip, deflate
Accept: */*
Connection: keep-alive
b'HTTP/1.1 200 \r\nServer: openresty/1.21.4.3\r\nDate: Wed, 20 Mar 2024 19:25:54 GMT\r\nContent-Type: text/plain;charset=UTF-8\r\nContent-Length: 640\r\nConnection: keep-alive\r\n'
b'{ "isCarPresent": false, "moreInfo": StatementCallback; bad SQL grammar [select * from cars where id=\'lwutw<lwutwlwutw-->lwutwlwutw*/lwutwlwutw*/:("\'lwutwlwutw:lwutwlwutw\nlwutwlwutw"lwutwlwutw\'lwutwlwutw`lwutwlwutw =lwutw\']; nested exception is org.h2.jdbc.JdbcSQLException: Syntax error in SQL statement "select * from cars where id=\'lwutw<lwutwlwutw-->lwutwlwutw*/lwutwlwutw*/:(""\'lwutwlwutw:lwutwlwutw\nlwutwlwutw[*]""lwutwlwutw\'lwutwlwutw`lwutwlwutw =lwutw\'"; SQL statement:\nselect * from cars where id=\'lwutw<lwutwlwutw-->lwutwlwutw*/lwutwlwutw*/:("\'lwutwlwutw:lwutwlwutw\nlwutwlwutw"lwutwlwutw\'lwutwlwutw`lwutwlwutw =lwutw\' [42000-176]}'

Cross site scripting vulnerability

MEDIUM

Summary

A Cross Site Scripting vulnerability was found at: "http://localhost/VulnerableApp/ErrorBasedSQLInjectionVulnerability/LEVEL_3", using HTTP method GET. The sent data was: "id=fwtkx%3Cfwtkx" The modified parameter was "id". This vulnerability was found in the request with id 5778.


Description

Client-side scripts are used extensively by modern web applications. They perform from simple functions (such as the formatting of text) up to full manipulation of client-side data and Operating System interaction.

Cross Site Scripting (XSS) allows clients to inject arbitrary scripting code into a request and have the server return the script to the client in the response. This occurs because the application is taking untrusted data (in this example, from the client) and reusing it without performing any validation or encoding.

  • Vulnerable URL: http://localhost/VulnerableApp/ErrorBasedSQLInjectionVulnerability/LEVEL_3
  • Vulnerable Parameter: id

Fix

To remedy XSS vulnerabilities, it is important to never use untrusted or unfiltered data within the code of a HTML page.

Untrusted data can originate not only form the client but potentially a third party or previously uploaded file etc. Filtering of untrusted data typically involves converting special characters to their HTML entity encoded counterparts (however, other methods do exist, see references). These special characters include:

  • &
  • <
  • >
  • "
  • '
  • /

An example of HTML entity encoding is converting < to &lt;. Although it is possible to filter untrusted input, there are five locations within an HTML page where untrusted input (even if it has been filtered) should never be placed:

  1. Directly in a script.
  2. Inside an HTML comment.
  3. In an attribute name.
  4. In a tag name.
  5. Directly in CSS.

Each of these locations have their own form of escaping and filtering.

Because many browsers attempt to implement XSS protection, any manual verification of this finding should be conducted using multiple different browsers and browser versions.

References

  • WASC
  • Secunia
  • OWASP

HTTP proof

GET http://localhost/VulnerableApp/ErrorBasedSQLInjectionVulnerability/LEVEL_3?id=fwtkx%3Cfwtkx HTTP/1.1
User-agent: python-requests/2.31.0
Host: localhost
Accept-encoding: gzip, deflate
Accept: */*
Connection: keep-alive
b'HTTP/1.1 200 \r\nServer: openresty/1.21.4.3\r\nDate: Wed, 20 Mar 2024 19:26:10 GMT\r\nContent-Type: text/plain;charset=UTF-8\r\nContent-Length: 390\r\nConnection: keep-alive\r\n'
b'{ "isCarPresent": false, "moreInfo": StatementCallback; SQL [select * from cars where id=\'fwtkx<fwtkx\']; Data conversion error converting "fwtkx<fwtkx"; SQL statement:\nselect * from cars where id=\'fwtkx<fwtkx\' [22018-176]; nested exception is org.h2.jdbc.JdbcSQLException: Data conversion error converting "fwtkx<fwtkx"; SQL statement:\nselect * from cars where id=\'fwtkx<fwtkx\' [22018-176]}'

Cross site scripting vulnerability

MEDIUM

Summary

A Cross Site Scripting vulnerability was found at: "http://localhost/VulnerableApp/ErrorBasedSQLInjectionVulnerability/LEVEL_4", using HTTP method GET. The sent data was: "id=owyap%3Cowyap" The modified parameter was "id". This vulnerability was found in the request with id 6002.


Description

Client-side scripts are used extensively by modern web applications. They perform from simple functions (such as the formatting of text) up to full manipulation of client-side data and Operating System interaction.

Cross Site Scripting (XSS) allows clients to inject arbitrary scripting code into a request and have the server return the script to the client in the response. This occurs because the application is taking untrusted data (in this example, from the client) and reusing it without performing any validation or encoding.

  • Vulnerable URL: http://localhost/VulnerableApp/ErrorBasedSQLInjectionVulnerability/LEVEL_4
  • Vulnerable Parameter: id

Fix

To remedy XSS vulnerabilities, it is important to never use untrusted or unfiltered data within the code of a HTML page.

Untrusted data can originate not only form the client but potentially a third party or previously uploaded file etc. Filtering of untrusted data typically involves converting special characters to their HTML entity encoded counterparts (however, other methods do exist, see references). These special characters include:

  • &
  • <
  • >
  • "
  • '
  • /

An example of HTML entity encoding is converting < to &lt;. Although it is possible to filter untrusted input, there are five locations within an HTML page where untrusted input (even if it has been filtered) should never be placed:

  1. Directly in a script.
  2. Inside an HTML comment.
  3. In an attribute name.
  4. In a tag name.
  5. Directly in CSS.

Each of these locations have their own form of escaping and filtering.

Because many browsers attempt to implement XSS protection, any manual verification of this finding should be conducted using multiple different browsers and browser versions.

References

  • WASC
  • Secunia
  • OWASP

HTTP proof

GET http://localhost/VulnerableApp/ErrorBasedSQLInjectionVulnerability/LEVEL_4?id=owyap%3Cowyap HTTP/1.1
User-agent: python-requests/2.31.0
Host: localhost
Accept-encoding: gzip, deflate
Accept: */*
Connection: keep-alive
b'HTTP/1.1 200 \r\nServer: openresty/1.21.4.3\r\nDate: Wed, 20 Mar 2024 19:26:24 GMT\r\nContent-Type: text/plain;charset=UTF-8\r\nContent-Length: 349\r\nConnection: keep-alive\r\n'
b'{ "isCarPresent": false, "moreInfo": PreparedStatementCallback; Data conversion error converting "owyap<owyap"; SQL statement:\nselect * from cars where id=\'owyap<owyap\' [22018-176]; nested exception is org.h2.jdbc.JdbcSQLException: Data conversion error converting "owyap<owyap"; SQL statement:\nselect * from cars where id=\'owyap<owyap\' [22018-176]}'

Insecure redirection

MEDIUM

Summary

Global redirect was found at: "http://localhost/VulnerableApp/Http3xxStatusCodeBasedInjection/LEVEL_1", using HTTP method GET. The sent data was: "returnTo=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.w4af.net%2F" The modified parameter was "returnTo". This vulnerability was found in the request with id 6482.


Description

Web applications occasionally use parameter values to store the address of the page to which the client will be redirected -- for example: yoursite.com/page.asp?redirect=www.yoursite.com/404.asp

An unvalidated redirect occurs when the client is able to modify the affected parameter value in the request and thus control the location of the redirection. For example, the following URL yoursite.com/page.asp?redirect=www.anothersite.com will redirect to www.anothersite.com.

Cyber-criminals will abuse these vulnerabilities in social engineering attacks to get users to unknowingly visit malicious web sites.

The tool has discovered that the server does not validate the parameter value prior to redirecting the client to the injected value.

  • Vulnerable URL: http://localhost/VulnerableApp/Http3xxStatusCodeBasedInjection/LEVEL_1
  • Vulnerable Parameter: returnTo

Fix

The application should ensure that the supplied value for a redirect is permitted. This can be achieved by performing whitelisting on the parameter value.

The whitelist should contain a list of pages or sites that the application is permitted to redirect users to. If the supplied value does not match any value in the whitelist then the server should redirect to a standard error page.

References

  • OWASP Top 10 2010

HTTP proof

GET http://localhost/VulnerableApp/Http3xxStatusCodeBasedInjection/LEVEL_1?returnTo=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.w4af.net%2F HTTP/1.1
User-agent: python-requests/2.31.0
Host: localhost
Accept-encoding: gzip, deflate
Accept: */*
Connection: keep-alive
b'HTTP/1.1 302 \r\nServer: openresty/1.21.4.3\r\nDate: Wed, 20 Mar 2024 19:26:44 GMT\r\nContent-Length: 0\r\nConnection: keep-alive\r\nLocation: http://www.w4af.net/\r\n'
b''

Insecure redirection

MEDIUM

Summary

Global redirect was found at: "http://localhost/VulnerableApp/Http3xxStatusCodeBasedInjection/LEVEL_2", using HTTP method GET. The sent data was: "returnTo=%2F%2Fw4af.net" The modified parameter was "returnTo". This vulnerability was found in the request with id 6717.


Description

Web applications occasionally use parameter values to store the address of the page to which the client will be redirected -- for example: yoursite.com/page.asp?redirect=www.yoursite.com/404.asp

An unvalidated redirect occurs when the client is able to modify the affected parameter value in the request and thus control the location of the redirection. For example, the following URL yoursite.com/page.asp?redirect=www.anothersite.com will redirect to www.anothersite.com.

Cyber-criminals will abuse these vulnerabilities in social engineering attacks to get users to unknowingly visit malicious web sites.

The tool has discovered that the server does not validate the parameter value prior to redirecting the client to the injected value.

  • Vulnerable URL: http://localhost/VulnerableApp/Http3xxStatusCodeBasedInjection/LEVEL_2
  • Vulnerable Parameter: returnTo

Fix

The application should ensure that the supplied value for a redirect is permitted. This can be achieved by performing whitelisting on the parameter value.

The whitelist should contain a list of pages or sites that the application is permitted to redirect users to. If the supplied value does not match any value in the whitelist then the server should redirect to a standard error page.

References

  • OWASP Top 10 2010

HTTP proof

GET http://localhost/VulnerableApp/Http3xxStatusCodeBasedInjection/LEVEL_2?returnTo=%2F%2Fw4af.net HTTP/1.1
User-agent: python-requests/2.31.0
Host: localhost
Accept-encoding: gzip, deflate
Accept: */*
Connection: keep-alive
b'HTTP/1.1 302 \r\nServer: openresty/1.21.4.3\r\nDate: Wed, 20 Mar 2024 19:26:50 GMT\r\nContent-Length: 0\r\nConnection: keep-alive\r\nLocation: //w4af.net\r\n'
b''

Blind SQL injection vulnerability

HIGH

Summary

Blind SQL injection was found at: "b'http://localhost/VulnerableApp/ErrorBasedSQLInjectionVulnerability/LEVEL_4'", using HTTP method b'GET'. The injectable parameter is: "b'id'". This vulnerability was found in the requests with ids 6597 and 6714.


Description

Due to the requirement for dynamic content of today's web applications, many rely on a database backend to store data that will be called upon and processed by the web application (or other programs). Web applications retrieve data from the database by using Structured Query Language (SQL) queries.

To meet demands of many developers, database servers (such as MSSQL, MySQL, Oracle etc.) have additional built-in functionality that can allow extensive control of the database and interaction with the host operating system itself. An SQL injection occurs when a value originating from the client's request is used within a SQL query without prior sanitisation. This could allow cyber-criminals to execute arbitrary SQL code and steal data or use the additional functionality of the database server to take control of more server components.

The successful exploitation of a SQL injection can be devastating to an organisation and is one of the most commonly exploited web application vulnerabilities.

Injection was detected as it was possible to inject specific SQL queries, that if vulnerable, result in the responses for each injection being different. This is known as a blind SQL injection vulnerability.

  • Vulnerable URL: http://localhost/VulnerableApp/ErrorBasedSQLInjectionVulnerability/LEVEL_4
  • Vulnerable Parameter: id

Fix

The only proven method to prevent against SQL injection attacks while still maintaining full application functionality is to use parameterized queries (also known as prepared statements). When utilising this method of querying the database, any value supplied by the client will be handled as a string value rather than part of the SQL query.

Additionally, when utilising parameterized queries, the database engine will automatically check to make sure the string being used matches that of the column. For example, the database engine will check that the user supplied input is an integer if the database column is configured to contain integers.

References

  • MITRE - CAPEC
  • WASC
  • W3 Schools
  • OWASP

HTTP proof

GET http://localhost/VulnerableApp/ErrorBasedSQLInjectionVulnerability/LEVEL_4?id=46%27%20OR%20%2746%27%3D%2746%27%20OR%20%2746%27%3D%2746 HTTP/1.1
User-agent: python-requests/2.31.0
Host: localhost
Accept-encoding: gzip, deflate
Accept: */*
Connection: keep-alive
b'HTTP/1.1 200 \r\nServer: openresty/1.21.4.3\r\nDate: Wed, 20 Mar 2024 19:26:47 GMT\r\nContent-Type: text/plain;charset=UTF-8\r\nContent-Length: 433\r\nConnection: keep-alive\r\n'
b'{ "isCarPresent": false, "moreInfo": PreparedStatementCallback; Data conversion error converting "46"" OR ""46""=""46"" OR ""46""=""46"; SQL statement:\nselect * from cars where id=\'46" OR "46"="46" OR "46"="46\' [22018-176]; nested exception is org.h2.jdbc.JdbcSQLException: Data conversion error converting "46"" OR ""46""=""46"" OR ""46""=""46"; SQL statement:\nselect * from cars where id=\'46" OR "46"="46" OR "46"="46\' [22018-176]}'
GET http://localhost/VulnerableApp/ErrorBasedSQLInjectionVulnerability/LEVEL_4?id=46%27%20OR%20%2746%27%3D%2746%27%20OR%20%2746%27%3D%2746 HTTP/1.1
User-agent: python-requests/2.31.0
Host: localhost
Accept-encoding: gzip, deflate
Accept: */*
Connection: keep-alive
b'HTTP/1.1 200 \r\nServer: openresty/1.21.4.3\r\nDate: Wed, 20 Mar 2024 19:26:50 GMT\r\nContent-Type: text/plain;charset=UTF-8\r\nContent-Length: 377\r\nConnection: keep-alive\r\n'
b'{ "isCarPresent": false, "moreInfo": PreparedStatementCallback; Data conversion error converting "46"" AND ""46""=""47"; SQL statement:\nselect * from cars where id=\'46" AND "46"="47\' [22018-176]; nested exception is org.h2.jdbc.JdbcSQLException: Data conversion error converting "46"" AND ""46""=""47"; SQL statement:\nselect * from cars where id=\'46" AND "46"="47\' [22018-176]}'

Insecure redirection

MEDIUM

Summary

Global redirect was found at: "http://localhost/VulnerableApp/Http3xxStatusCodeBasedInjection/LEVEL_3", using HTTP method GET. The sent data was: "returnTo=localhost.w4af.net" The modified parameter was "returnTo". This vulnerability was found in the request with id 7870.


Description

Web applications occasionally use parameter values to store the address of the page to which the client will be redirected -- for example: yoursite.com/page.asp?redirect=www.yoursite.com/404.asp

An unvalidated redirect occurs when the client is able to modify the affected parameter value in the request and thus control the location of the redirection. For example, the following URL yoursite.com/page.asp?redirect=www.anothersite.com will redirect to www.anothersite.com.

Cyber-criminals will abuse these vulnerabilities in social engineering attacks to get users to unknowingly visit malicious web sites.

The tool has discovered that the server does not validate the parameter value prior to redirecting the client to the injected value.

  • Vulnerable URL: http://localhost/VulnerableApp/Http3xxStatusCodeBasedInjection/LEVEL_3
  • Vulnerable Parameter: returnTo

Fix

The application should ensure that the supplied value for a redirect is permitted. This can be achieved by performing whitelisting on the parameter value.

The whitelist should contain a list of pages or sites that the application is permitted to redirect users to. If the supplied value does not match any value in the whitelist then the server should redirect to a standard error page.

References

  • OWASP Top 10 2010

HTTP proof

GET http://localhost/VulnerableApp/Http3xxStatusCodeBasedInjection/LEVEL_3?returnTo=localhost.w4af.net HTTP/1.1
User-agent: python-requests/2.31.0
Host: localhost
Accept-encoding: gzip, deflate
Accept: */*
Connection: keep-alive
b'HTTP/1.1 302 \r\nServer: openresty/1.21.4.3\r\nDate: Wed, 20 Mar 2024 19:27:21 GMT\r\nContent-Length: 0\r\nConnection: keep-alive\r\nLocation: localhost.w4af.net\r\n'
b''

Insecure redirection

MEDIUM

Summary

Global redirect was found at: "http://localhost/VulnerableApp/Http3xxStatusCodeBasedInjection/LEVEL_4", using HTTP method GET. The sent data was: "returnTo=localhost.w4af.net" The modified parameter was "returnTo". This vulnerability was found in the request with id 7875.


Description

Web applications occasionally use parameter values to store the address of the page to which the client will be redirected -- for example: yoursite.com/page.asp?redirect=www.yoursite.com/404.asp

An unvalidated redirect occurs when the client is able to modify the affected parameter value in the request and thus control the location of the redirection. For example, the following URL yoursite.com/page.asp?redirect=www.anothersite.com will redirect to www.anothersite.com.

Cyber-criminals will abuse these vulnerabilities in social engineering attacks to get users to unknowingly visit malicious web sites.

The tool has discovered that the server does not validate the parameter value prior to redirecting the client to the injected value.

  • Vulnerable URL: http://localhost/VulnerableApp/Http3xxStatusCodeBasedInjection/LEVEL_4
  • Vulnerable Parameter: returnTo

The whitelist should contain a list of pages or sites that the application is permitted to redirect users to. If the supplied value does not match any value in the whitelist then the server should redirect to a standard error page.

Insecure redirection

MEDIUM

Summary

Global redirect was found at: "http://localhost/VulnerableApp/Http3xxStatusCodeBasedInjection/LEVEL_5", using HTTP method GET. The sent data was: "returnTo=localhost.w4af.net" The modified parameter was "returnTo". This vulnerability was found in the request with id 7898.

Web applications occasionally use parameter values to store the address of the page to which the client will be redirected -- for example: yoursite.com/page.asp?redirect=www.yoursite.com/404.asp

An unvalidated redirect occurs when the client is able to modify the affected parameter value in the request and thus control the location of the redirection. For example, the following URL yoursite.com/page.asp?redirect=www.anothersite.com will redirect to www.anothersite.com.

Cyber-criminals will abuse these vulnerabilities in social engineering attacks to get users to unknowingly visit malicious web sites.

The tool has discovered that the server does not validate the parameter value prior to redirecting the client to the injected value.

  • Vulnerable URL: http://localhost/VulnerableApp/Http3xxStatusCodeBasedInjection/LEVEL_5
  • Vulnerable Parameter: returnTo

Fix

The application should ensure that the supplied value for a redirect is permitted. This can be achieved by performing whitelisting on the parameter value.

The whitelist should contain a list of pages or sites that the application is permitted to redirect users to. If the supplied value does not match any value in the whitelist then the server should redirect to a standard error page.

References

  • OWASP Top 10 2010

ReDoS vulnerability

MEDIUM

Summary

ReDoS was found at: "http://localhost/VulnerableApp/Http3xxStatusCodeBasedInjection/LEVEL_8", using HTTP method GET. The sent data was: "returnTo=%2F%0A" The modified parameter was "returnTo". This vulnerability was found in the requests with ids 8067, 8093, 8103, 8119 and 8143.

  • Vulnerable URL: http://localhost/VulnerableApp/Http3xxStatusCodeBasedInjection/LEVEL_8
  • Vulnerable Parameter: returnTo

Cross site scripting vulnerability

MEDIUM

Summary

A Cross Site Scripting vulnerability was found at: "http://localhost/VulnerableApp/PersistentXSSInHTMLTagVulnerability/LEVEL_1", using HTTP method GET. The sent data was: "comment=rbf7i%3Crbf7i" The modified parameter was "comment". This vulnerability was found in the request with id 13334.


Description

Client-side scripts are used extensively by modern web applications. They perform from simple functions (such as the formatting of text) up to full manipulation of client-side data and Operating System interaction.

Cross Site Scripting (XSS) allows clients to inject arbitrary scripting code into a request and have the server return the script to the client in the response. This occurs because the application is taking untrusted data (in this example, from the client) and reusing it without performing any validation or encoding.

  • Vulnerable URL: http://localhost/VulnerableApp/PersistentXSSInHTMLTagVulnerability/LEVEL_1
  • Vulnerable Parameter: comment

Fix

To remedy XSS vulnerabilities, it is important to never use untrusted or unfiltered data within the code of a HTML page.

Untrusted data can originate not only form the client but potentially a third party or previously uploaded file etc. Filtering of untrusted data typically involves converting special characters to their HTML entity encoded counterparts (however, other methods do exist, see references). These special characters include:

  • &
  • <
  • >
  • "
  • '
  • /

An example of HTML entity encoding is converting < to &lt;. Although it is possible to filter untrusted input, there are five locations within an HTML page where untrusted input (even if it has been filtered) should never be placed:

  1. Directly in a script.
  2. Inside an HTML comment.
  3. In an attribute name.
  4. In a tag name.
  5. Directly in CSS.

Each of these locations have their own form of escaping and filtering.

Because many browsers attempt to implement XSS protection, any manual verification of this finding should be conducted using multiple different browsers and browser versions.

References

  • WASC
  • Secunia
  • OWASP

HTTP proof

GET http://localhost/VulnerableApp/PersistentXSSInHTMLTagVulnerability/LEVEL_1?comment=rbf7i%3Crbf7i HTTP/1.1
User-agent: python-requests/2.31.0
Host: localhost
Accept-encoding: gzip, deflate
Accept: */*
Connection: keep-alive

Authentication without www-authenticate header

INFO

Summary

The resource: "http://localhost/VulnerableApp/JWTVulnerability/LEVEL_1" requires authentication (HTTP Code 401) but the www-authenticate header is not present. This requires human verification. This information was found in the request with id 8231.

  • Vulnerable URL: http://localhost/VulnerableApp/JWTVulnerability/LEVEL_1

HTTP proof

GET http://localhost/VulnerableApp/JWTVulnerability/LEVEL_1?JWT=type%20%25SYSTEMROOT%25%5Cwin.ini HTTP/1.1
User-agent: python-requests/2.31.0
Host: localhost
Accept-encoding: gzip, deflate
Accept: */*
Connection: keep-alive
b'HTTP/1.1 401 \r\nServer: openresty/1.21.4.3\r\nDate: Wed, 20 Mar 2024 19:27:29 GMT\r\nContent-Type: application/json\r\nTransfer-Encoding: chunked\r\nConnection: keep-alive\r\n'
b'{"content":"type %SYSTEMROOT%\\\\win.ini","isValid":false}'

Path disclosure vulnerability

LOW

Summary

The URL: "http://localhost/VulnerableApp/PersistentXSSInHTMLTagVulnerability/LEVEL_1" has a path disclosure vulnerability which discloses "/bin/cat". This vulnerability was found in the request with id 13270.

Path disclosure vulnerability

LOW

Summary

The URL: "http://localhost/VulnerableApp/PersistentXSSInHTMLTagVulnerability/LEVEL_1" has a path disclosure vulnerability which discloses "/usr/sbin/ping". This vulnerability was found in the request with id 13356.

  • Vulnerable URL: http://localhost/VulnerableApp/PersistentXSSInHTMLTagVulnerability/LEVEL_1

id="comments">jwl4o\njwl4o</div><div id="comments">z7m26"z7m26</div><div id="comments">e94sm\'e94sm</div><div id="comments">34ejj`34ejj</div><div id="comments">qxxca =qxxca</div><div id="comments">//w4af.net</div><div id="comments">http://www.w4af.net/</div><div id="comments">90 AND 90=91 </div><div id="comments">AWvQIRdUANpVKLywQHwweTFi\n</div><div id="comments">89\' AND \'89\'=\'90</div><div id="comments">39" AND "39"="40</div><div id="comments">a\'b"c\'d"</div><div id="comments">a\'b"c\'d"</div><div id="comments">AWvQIRdUANpVKLywQHwweTFi\n</div><div id="comments">a\'b"c\'d"</div><div id="comments">39 OR 39 39 OR 39 39</div><div id="comments">aaaaaaaaaaX!</div><div id="comments">a@a.aaaaaaaaaaX!</div><div id="comments">&&/usr/sbin/ping -s localhost 9</div>'

Cross site scripting vulnerability

MEDIUM

Summary

A Cross Site Scripting vulnerability was found at: "http://localhost/VulnerableApp/PersistentXSSInHTMLTagVulnerability/LEVEL_2", using HTTP method GET. The sent data was: "comment=" The modified parameter was "comment". This vulnerability was found in the request with id 13449.


Description

Client-side scripts are used extensively by modern web applications. They perform from simple functions (such as the formatting of text) up to full manipulation of client-side data and Operating System interaction.

Cross Site Scripting (XSS) allows clients to inject arbitrary scripting code into a request and have the server return the script to the client in the response. This occurs because the application is taking untrusted data (in this example, from the client) and reusing it without performing any validation or encoding.

  • Vulnerable URL: http://localhost/VulnerableApp/PersistentXSSInHTMLTagVulnerability/LEVEL_2
  • Vulnerable Parameter: comment

Fix

To remedy XSS vulnerabilities, it is important to never use untrusted or unfiltered data within the code of a HTML page.

Untrusted data can originate not only form the client but potentially a third party or previously uploaded file etc. Filtering of untrusted data typically involves converting special characters to their HTML entity encoded counterparts (however, other methods do exist, see references). These special characters include:

  • &
  • <
  • >
  • "
  • '
  • /

An example of HTML entity encoding is converting < to &lt;. Although it is possible to filter untrusted input, there are five locations within an HTML page where untrusted input (even if it has been filtered) should never be placed:

  1. Directly in a script.
  2. Inside an HTML comment.
  3. In an attribute name.
  4. In a tag name.
  5. Directly in CSS.

Each of these locations have their own form of escaping and filtering.

Because many browsers attempt to implement XSS protection, any manual verification of this finding should be conducted using multiple different browsers and browser versions.

References

  • WASC
  • Secunia
  • OWASP

HTTP proof

GET http://localhost/VulnerableApp/PersistentXSSInHTMLTagVulnerability/LEVEL_2?comment=b3hkj%3Cb3hkjb3hkj--%3Eb3hkjb3hkj%2A%2Fb3hkjb3hkj%2A%2F%3A%28%22%27b3hkjb3hkj%3Ab3hkjb3hkj%0Ab3hkjb3hkj%22b3hkjb3hkj%27b3hkjb3hkj%60b3hkjb3hkj%20%3Db3hkj HTTP/1.1
User-agent: python-requests/2.31.0
Host: localhost
Accept-encoding: gzip, deflate
Accept: */*
Connection: keep-alive
b'HTTP/1.1 200 \r\nServer: openresty/1.21.4.3\r\nDate: Wed, 20 Mar 2024 19:31:10 GMT\r\nContent-Type: text/plain;charset=UTF-8\r\nContent-Length: 1130\r\nConnection: keep-alive\r\n'
b'<div id="comments">AWvQIRdUANpVKLywQHwweTFi\n</div><div id="comments">AWvQIRdUANpVKLywQHwweTFi\n</div><div id="comments">AWvQIRdUANpVKLywQHwweTFi\n</div><div id="comments">AWvQIRdUANpVKLywQHwweTFi\n</div><div id="comments"><!--#exec cmd="echo -n 81882;echo -n 51327" --></div><div id="comments"><!--#set var="SEED_A" value="21954" --><!--#echo var="SEED_A" --><!--#set var="SEED_B" value="98939" --><!--#echo var="SEED_B" --></div><div id="comments">{math equation="x * y" x=53237 y=26991}</div><div id="comments">${29461 * 87164}</div><div id="comments">{{41989 * 77973}}</div><div id="comments">{43817 * 51848}</div><div id="comments">%n</div><div id="comments">%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n</div><div id="comments">%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n</div><div id="comments">%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n%n</div><div id="comments">b3hkj<b3hkjb3hkj-->b3hkjb3hkj*/b3hkjb3hkj*/:("\'b3hkjb3hkj:b3hkjb3hkj\nb3hkjb3hkj"b3hkjb3hkj\'b3hkjb3hkj`b3hkjb3hkj =b3hkj</div>'

Cross site scripting vulnerability

MEDIUM

Summary

A Cross Site Scripting vulnerability was found at: "http://localhost/VulnerableApp/PersistentXSSInHTMLTagVulnerability/LEVEL_3", using HTTP method GET. The sent data was: "comment=" The modified parameter was "comment". This vulnerability was found in the request with id 13760.


Description

Client-side scripts are used extensively by modern web applications. They perform from simple functions (such as the formatting of text) up to full manipulation of client-side data and Operating System interaction.

Cross Site Scripting (XSS) allows clients to inject arbitrary scripting code into a request and have the server return the script to the client in the response. This occurs because the application is taking untrusted data (in this example, from the client) and reusing it without performing any validation or encoding.

  • Vulnerable URL: http://localhost/VulnerableApp/PersistentXSSInHTMLTagVulnerability/LEVEL_3
  • Vulnerable Parameter: comment

Fix

To remedy XSS vulnerabilities, it is important to never use untrusted or unfiltered data within the code of a HTML page.

Untrusted data can originate not only form the client but potentially a third party or previously uploaded file etc. Filtering of untrusted data typically involves converting special characters to their HTML entity encoded counterparts (however, other methods do exist, see references). These special characters include:

  • &
  • <
  • >
  • "
  • '
  • /

An example of HTML entity encoding is converting < to &lt;. Although it is possible to filter untrusted input, there are five locations within an HTML page where untrusted input (even if it has been filtered) should never be placed:

  1. Directly in a script.
  2. Inside an HTML comment.
  3. In an attribute name.
  4. In a tag name.
  5. Directly in CSS.

Each of these locations have their own form of escaping and filtering.

Because many browsers attempt to implement XSS protection, any manual verification of this finding should be conducted using multiple different browsers and browser versions.

References

  • WASC
  • Secunia
  • OWASP

Cross site scripting vulnerability

MEDIUM

Summary

A Cross Site Scripting vulnerability was found at: "http://localhost/VulnerableApp/PersistentXSSInHTMLTagVulnerability/LEVEL_4", using HTTP method GET. The sent data was: "comment=" The modified parameter was "comment". This vulnerability was found in the request with id 13968.


Description

Client-side scripts are used extensively by modern web applications. They perform from simple functions (such as the formatting of text) up to full manipulation of client-side data and Operating System interaction.

Cross Site Scripting (XSS) allows clients to inject arbitrary scripting code into a request and have the server return the script to the client in the response. This occurs because the application is taking untrusted data (in this example, from the client) and reusing it without performing any validation or encoding.

  • Vulnerable URL: http://localhost/VulnerableApp/PersistentXSSInHTMLTagVulnerability/LEVEL_4
  • Vulnerable Parameter: comment

Fix

To remedy XSS vulnerabilities, it is important to never use untrusted or unfiltered data within the code of a HTML page.

Untrusted data can originate not only form the client but potentially a third party or previously uploaded file etc. Filtering of untrusted data typically involves converting special characters to their HTML entity encoded counterparts (however, other methods do exist, see references). These special characters include:

  • &
  • <
  • >
  • "
  • '
  • /

An example of HTML entity encoding is converting < to &lt;. Although it is possible to filter untrusted input, there are five locations within an HTML page where untrusted input (even if it has been filtered) should never be placed:

  1. Directly in a script.
  2. Inside an HTML comment.
  3. In an attribute name.
  4. In a tag name.
  5. Directly in CSS.

Each of these locations have their own form of escaping and filtering.

Because many browsers attempt to implement XSS protection, any manual verification of this finding should be conducted using multiple different browsers and browser versions.

References

  • WASC
  • Secunia
  • OWASP

Cross site scripting vulnerability

MEDIUM

Summary

A Cross Site Scripting vulnerability was found at: "http://localhost/VulnerableApp/PersistentXSSInHTMLTagVulnerability/LEVEL_5", using HTTP method GET. The sent data was: "comment=" The modified parameter was "comment". This vulnerability was found in the request with id 14218.


Description

Client-side scripts are used extensively by modern web applications. They perform from simple functions (such as the formatting of text) up to full manipulation of client-side data and Operating System interaction.

Cross Site Scripting (XSS) allows clients to inject arbitrary scripting code into a request and have the server return the script to the client in the response. This occurs because the application is taking untrusted data (in this example, from the client) and reusing it without performing any validation or encoding.

  • Vulnerable URL: http://localhost/VulnerableApp/PersistentXSSInHTMLTagVulnerability/LEVEL_5
  • Vulnerable Parameter: comment

Fix

To remedy XSS vulnerabilities, it is important to never use untrusted or unfiltered data within the code of a HTML page.

Untrusted data can originate not only form the client but potentially a third party or previously uploaded file etc. Filtering of untrusted data typically involves converting special characters to their HTML entity encoded counterparts (however, other methods do exist, see references). These special characters include:

  • &
  • <
  • >
  • "
  • '
  • /

An example of HTML entity encoding is converting < to &lt;. Although it is possible to filter untrusted input, there are five locations within an HTML page where untrusted input (even if it has been filtered) should never be placed:

  1. Directly in a script.
  2. Inside an HTML comment.
  3. In an attribute name.
  4. In a tag name.
  5. Directly in CSS.

Each of these locations have their own form of escaping and filtering.

Because many browsers attempt to implement XSS protection, any manual verification of this finding should be conducted using multiple different browsers and browser versions.

References

  • WASC
  • Secunia
  • OWASP

HTTP proof

id="comments">qyzht<qyzhtqyzht-->qyzhtqyzht*/qyzhtqyzht*/:("\'qyzhtqyzht:qyzhtqyzht\nqyzhtqyzht"qyzhtqyzht\'qyzhtqyzht`qyzhtqyzht =qyzht</div>'

Local file inclusion vulnerability

MEDIUM

Summary

Local File Inclusion was found at: "http://localhost/VulnerableApp/SSRFVulnerability/LEVEL_1", using HTTP method GET. The sent data was: "fileurl=file%3A%2F%2F%2Fetc%2Fpasswd" The modified parameter was "fileurl". This vulnerability was found in the request with id 14950.


Description

Web applications occasionally use parameter values to store the location of a file which will later be required by the server.

An example of this is often seen in error pages, where the actual file path for the error page is stored in a parameter value -- for example example.com/error.php?page=404.php.

A file inclusion occurs when the parameter value (ie. path to file) can be substituted with the path of another resource on the same server, effectively allowing the displaying of arbitrary, and possibly restricted/sensitive, files. The tool discovered that it was possible to substitute a parameter value with another resource and have the server return the contents of the resource to the client within the response.

  • Vulnerable URL: http://localhost/VulnerableApp/SSRFVulnerability/LEVEL_1
  • Vulnerable Parameter: fileurl

Fix

It is recommended that untrusted data is never used to form a file location to be included.

To validate data, the application should ensure that the supplied value for a file is permitted. This can be achieved by performing whitelisting on the parameter value, by matching it against a list of permitted files. If the supplied value does not match any value in the whitelist, then the server should redirect to a standard error page.

In some scenarios, where dynamic content is being requested, it may not be possible to perform validation against a list of trusted resources, therefore the list must also become dynamic (updated as the files change), or perform filtering to remove extraneous user input (such as semicolons, periods etc.) and only permit a-z0-9.

It is also advised that sensitive files are not stored within the web root and that the user permissions enforced by the directory are correct.

References

  • OWASP

HTTP proof

GET http://localhost/VulnerableApp/SSRFVulnerability/LEVEL_1?fileurl=file%3A%2F%2F%2Fetc%2Fpasswd HTTP/1.1
User-agent: python-requests/2.31.0
Host: localhost
Accept-encoding: gzip, deflate
Accept: */*
Connection: keep-alive
b'HTTP/1.1 200 \r\nServer: openresty/1.21.4.3\r\nDate: Wed, 20 Mar 2024 19:35:45 GMT\r\nContent-Type: application/json\r\nTransfer-Encoding: chunked\r\nConnection: keep-alive\r\n'
b'{"content":"root:x:0:0:root:/root:/bin/ashbin:x:1:1:bin:/bin:/sbin/nologindaemon:x:2:2:daemon:/sbin:/sbin/nologinadm:x:3:4:adm:/var/adm:/sbin/nologinlp:x:4:7:lp:/var/spool/lpd:/sbin/nologinsync:x:5:0:sync:/sbin:/bin/syncshutdown:x:6:0:shutdown:/sbin:/sbin/shutdownhalt:x:7:0:halt:/sbin:/sbin/haltmail:x:8:12:mail:/var/spool/mail:/sbin/nologinnews:x:9:13:news:/usr/lib/news:/sbin/nologinuucp:x:10:14:uucp:/var/spool/uucppublic:/sbin/nologinoperator:x:11:0:operator:/root:/bin/shman:x:13:15:man:/usr/man:/sbin/nologinpostmaster:x:14:12:postmaster:/var/spool/mail:/sbin/nologincron:x:16:16:cron:/var/spool/cron:/sbin/nologinftp:x:21:21::/var/lib/ftp:/sbin/nologinsshd:x:22:22:sshd:/dev/null:/sbin/nologinat:x:25:25:at:/var/spool/cron/atjobs:/sbin/nologinsquid:x:31:31:Squid:/var/cache/squid:/sbin/nologinxfs:x:33:33:X Font Server:/etc/X11/fs:/sbin/nologingames:x:35:35:games:/usr/games:/sbin/nologinpostgres:x:70:70::/var/lib/postgresql:/bin/shcyrus:x:85:12::/usr/cyrus:/sbin/nologinvpopmail:x:89:89::/var/vpopmail:/sbin/nologinntp:x:123:123:NTP:/var/empty:/sbin/nologinsmmsp:x:209:209:smmsp:/var/spool/mqueue:/sbin/nologinguest:x:405:100:guest:/dev/null:/sbin/nologinnobody:x:65534:65534:nobody:/:/sbin/nologin","isValid":true}'

Blind SQL injection vulnerability

HIGH

Summary

Blind SQL injection was found at: "b'http://localhost/VulnerableApp/UnionBasedSQLInjectionVulnerability/LEVEL_1'", using HTTP method b'GET'. The injectable parameter is: "b'id'". This vulnerability was found in the requests with ids 16323 and 16332.


Description

Due to the requirement for dynamic content of today's web applications, many rely on a database backend to store data that will be called upon and processed by the web application (or other programs). Web applications retrieve data from the database by using Structured Query Language (SQL) queries.

To meet demands of many developers, database servers (such as MSSQL, MySQL, Oracle etc.) have additional built-in functionality that can allow extensive control of the database and interaction with the host operating system itself. An SQL injection occurs when a value originating from the client's request is used within a SQL query without prior sanitisation. This could allow cyber-criminals to execute arbitrary SQL code and steal data or use the additional functionality of the database server to take control of more server components.

The successful exploitation of a SQL injection can be devastating to an organisation and is one of the most commonly exploited web application vulnerabilities.

Injection was detected as it was possible to inject specific SQL queries, that if vulnerable, result in the responses for each injection being different. This is known as a blind SQL injection vulnerability.

  • Vulnerable URL: http://localhost/VulnerableApp/UnionBasedSQLInjectionVulnerability/LEVEL_1
  • Vulnerable Parameter: id

Fix

The only proven method to prevent against SQL injection attacks while still maintaining full application functionality is to use parameterized queries (also known as prepared statements). When utilising this method of querying the database, any value supplied by the client will be handled as a string value rather than part of the SQL query.

Additionally, when utilising parameterized queries, the database engine will automatically check to make sure the string being used matches that of the column. For example, the database engine will check that the user supplied input is an integer if the database column is configured to contain integers.

References

  • MITRE - CAPEC
  • WASC
  • W3 Schools
  • OWASP

HTTP proof

GET http://localhost/VulnerableApp/UnionBasedSQLInjectionVulnerability/LEVEL_1?id=66%27%20OR%20%2766%27%3D%2766%27%20OR%20%2766%27%3D%2766 HTTP/1.1
User-agent: python-requests/2.31.0
Host: localhost
Accept-encoding: gzip, deflate
Accept: */*
Connection: keep-alive
b'HTTP/1.1 200 \r\nServer: openresty/1.21.4.3\r\nDate: Wed, 20 Mar 2024 19:36:11 GMT\r\nContent-Type: application/json\r\nTransfer-Encoding: chunked\r\nConnection: keep-alive\r\n'
b'{"id":1,"name":"Audi","imagePath":"/VulnerableApp/images/cars/Audi.jpg"}'
GET http://localhost/VulnerableApp/UnionBasedSQLInjectionVulnerability/LEVEL_1?id=66%27%20OR%20%2766%27%3D%2766%27%20OR%20%2766%27%3D%2766 HTTP/1.1
User-agent: python-requests/2.31.0
Host: localhost
Accept-encoding: gzip, deflate
Accept: */*
Connection: keep-alive
b'HTTP/1.1 200 \r\nServer: openresty/1.21.4.3\r\nDate: Wed, 20 Mar 2024 19:36:11 GMT\r\nContent-Type: application/json\r\nTransfer-Encoding: chunked\r\nConnection: keep-alive\r\n'
b'{"id":0,"name":null,"imagePath":null}'

Blind SQL injection vulnerability

HIGH

Summary

Blind SQL injection was found at: "b'http://localhost/VulnerableApp/UnionBasedSQLInjectionVulnerability/LEVEL_2'", using HTTP method b'GET'. The injectable parameter is: "b'id'". This vulnerability was found in the requests with ids 16572 and 16583.


Description

Due to the requirement for dynamic content of today's web applications, many rely on a database backend to store data that will be called upon and processed by the web application (or other programs). Web applications retrieve data from the database by using Structured Query Language (SQL) queries.

To meet demands of many developers, database servers (such as MSSQL, MySQL, Oracle etc.) have additional built-in functionality that can allow extensive control of the database and interaction with the host operating system itself. An SQL injection occurs when a value originating from the client's request is used within a SQL query without prior sanitisation. This could allow cyber-criminals to execute arbitrary SQL code and steal data or use the additional functionality of the database server to take control of more server components.

The successful exploitation of a SQL injection can be devastating to an organisation and is one of the most commonly exploited web application vulnerabilities.

Injection was detected as it was possible to inject specific SQL queries, that if vulnerable, result in the responses for each injection being different. This is known as a blind SQL injection vulnerability.

  • Vulnerable URL: http://localhost/VulnerableApp/UnionBasedSQLInjectionVulnerability/LEVEL_2
  • Vulnerable Parameter: id

Fix

The only proven method to prevent against SQL injection attacks while still maintaining full application functionality is to use parameterized queries (also known as prepared statements). When utilising this method of querying the database, any value supplied by the client will be handled as a string value rather than part of the SQL query.

Additionally, when utilising parameterized queries, the database engine will automatically check to make sure the string being used matches that of the column. For example, the database engine will check that the user supplied input is an integer if the database column is configured to contain integers.

References

  • MITRE - CAPEC
  • WASC
  • W3 Schools
  • OWASP

HTTP proof

GET http://localhost/VulnerableApp/UnionBasedSQLInjectionVulnerability/LEVEL_2?id=71%22%20OR%20%2271%22%3D%2271%22%20OR%20%2271%22%3D%2271 HTTP/1.1
User-agent: python-requests/2.31.0
Host: localhost
Accept-encoding: gzip, deflate
Accept: */*
Connection: keep-alive
b'HTTP/1.1 200 \r\nServer: openresty/1.21.4.3\r\nDate: Wed, 20 Mar 2024 19:36:16 GMT\r\nContent-Type: application/json\r\nTransfer-Encoding: chunked\r\nConnection: keep-alive\r\n'
b'{"id":1,"name":"Audi","imagePath":"/VulnerableApp/images/cars/Audi.jpg"}'
GET http://localhost/VulnerableApp/UnionBasedSQLInjectionVulnerability/LEVEL_2?id=71%22%20OR%20%2271%22%3D%2271%22%20OR%20%2271%22%3D%2271 HTTP/1.1
User-agent: python-requests/2.31.0
Host: localhost
Accept-encoding: gzip, deflate
Accept: */*
Connection: keep-alive
b'HTTP/1.1 200 \r\nServer: openresty/1.21.4.3\r\nDate: Wed, 20 Mar 2024 19:36:16 GMT\r\nContent-Type: application/json\r\nTransfer-Encoding: chunked\r\nConnection: keep-alive\r\n'
b'{"id":0,"name":null,"imagePath":null}'

Cross site scripting vulnerability

MEDIUM

Summary

A Cross Site Scripting vulnerability was found at: "http://localhost/VulnerableApp/XSSInImgTagAttribute/LEVEL_1", using HTTP method GET. The sent data was: "src=" The modified parameter was "src". This vulnerability was found in the request with id 18011.


Description

Client-side scripts are used extensively by modern web applications. They perform from simple functions (such as the formatting of text) up to full manipulation of client-side data and Operating System interaction.

Cross Site Scripting (XSS) allows clients to inject arbitrary scripting code into a request and have the server return the script to the client in the response. This occurs because the application is taking untrusted data (in this example, from the client) and reusing it without performing any validation or encoding.

  • Vulnerable URL: http://localhost/VulnerableApp/XSSInImgTagAttribute/LEVEL_1
  • Vulnerable Parameter: src

Fix

To remedy XSS vulnerabilities, it is important to never use untrusted or unfiltered data within the code of a HTML page.

Untrusted data can originate not only form the client but potentially a third party or previously uploaded file etc. Filtering of untrusted data typically involves converting special characters to their HTML entity encoded counterparts (however, other methods do exist, see references). These special characters include:

  • &
  • <
  • >
  • "
  • '
  • /

An example of HTML entity encoding is converting < to &lt;. Although it is possible to filter untrusted input, there are five locations within an HTML page where untrusted input (even if it has been filtered) should never be placed:

  1. Directly in a script.
  2. Inside an HTML comment.
  3. In an attribute name.
  4. In a tag name.
  5. Directly in CSS.

Each of these locations have their own form of escaping and filtering.

Because many browsers attempt to implement XSS protection, any manual verification of this finding should be conducted using multiple different browsers and browser versions.

References

  • WASC
  • Secunia
  • OWASP

HTTP proof

GET http://localhost/VulnerableApp/XSSInImgTagAttribute/LEVEL_1?src=ludxv%3Cludxvludxv--%3Eludxvludxv%2A%2Fludxvludxv%2A%2F%3A%28%22%27ludxvludxv%3Aludxvludxv%0Aludxvludxv%22ludxvludxv%27ludxvludxv%60ludxvludxv%20%3Dludxv HTTP/1.1
User-agent: python-requests/2.31.0
Host: localhost
Accept-encoding: gzip, deflate
Accept: */*
Connection: keep-alive
b'HTTP/1.1 200 \r\nServer: openresty/1.21.4.3\r\nDate: Wed, 20 Mar 2024 19:36:38 GMT\r\nContent-Type: text/plain;charset=UTF-8\r\nContent-Length: 155\r\nConnection: keep-alive\r\n'
b'<img src=ludxv<ludxvludxv-->ludxvludxv*/ludxvludxv*/:("\'ludxvludxv:ludxvludxv\nludxvludxv"ludxvludxv\'ludxvludxv`ludxvludxv =ludxv width="400" height="300"/>'

Cross site scripting vulnerability

MEDIUM

Summary

A Cross Site Scripting vulnerability was found at: "http://localhost/VulnerableApp/XSSInImgTagAttribute/LEVEL_2", using HTTP method GET. The sent data was: "src=" The modified parameter was "src". This vulnerability was found in the request with id 18226.


Description

Client-side scripts are used extensively by modern web applications. They perform from simple functions (such as the formatting of text) up to full manipulation of client-side data and Operating System interaction.

Cross Site Scripting (XSS) allows clients to inject arbitrary scripting code into a request and have the server return the script to the client in the response.   • Vulnerable Parameter: src

  • &
  • <
  • >
  • "
  • '
  • /

An example of HTML entity encoding is converting < to &lt;. Although it is possible to filter untrusted input, there are five locations within an HTML page where untrusted input (even if it has been filtered) should never be placed:

  1. Directly in a script.
  2. Inside an HTML comment.
  3. In an attribute name.
  4. In a tag name.
  5. Directly in CSS.

Each of these locations have their own form of escaping and filtering.

Because many browsers attempt to implement XSS protection, any manual verification of this finding should be conducted using multiple different browsers and browser versions.

References

  • WASC
  • Secunia
  • OWASP

HTTP proof

GET http://localhost/VulnerableApp/XSSInImgTagAttribute/LEVEL_2?src=jowsl%3Cjowsljowsl--%3Ejowsljowsl%2A%2Fjowsljowsl%2A%2F%3A%28%22%27jowsljowsl%3Ajowsljowsl%0Ajowsljowsl%22jowsljowsl%27jowsljowsl%60jowsljowsl%20%3Djowsl HTTP/1.1
User-agent: python-requests/2.31.0
Host: localhost
Accept-encoding: gzip, deflate
Accept: */*
Connection: keep-alive
b'HTTP/1.1 200 \r\nServer: openresty/1.21.4.3\r\nDate: Wed, 20 Mar 2024 19:36:42 GMT\r\nContent-Type: text/plain;charset=UTF-8\r\nContent-Length: 157\r\nConnection: keep-alive\r\n'
b'<img src="jowsl<jowsljowsl-->jowsljowsl*/jowsljowsl*/:("\'jowsljowsl:jowsljowsl\njowsljowsl"jowsljowsl\'jowsljowsl`jowsljowsl =jowsl" width="400" height="300"/>'

Cross site scripting vulnerability

MEDIUM

Summary

A Cross Site Scripting vulnerability was found at: "http://localhost/VulnerableApp/XSSInImgTagAttribute/LEVEL_3", using HTTP method GET. The sent data was: "src=3n6wo%3A3n6wo" The modified parameter was "src". This vulnerability was found in the request with id 18454.

  • &

  • >
  • "
  • '
  • /

HTTP proof

GET http://localhost/VulnerableApp/XSSInImgTagAttribute/LEVEL_3?src=3n6wo%3A3n6wo HTTP/1.1
User-agent: python-requests/2.31.0
Host: localhost
Accept-encoding: gzip, deflate
Accept: */*
Connection: keep-alive
b'HTTP/1.1 200 \r\nServer: openresty/1.21.4.3\r\nDate: Wed, 20 Mar 2024 19:36:46 GMT\r\nContent-Type: text/plain;charset=UTF-8\r\nContent-Length: 47\r\nConnection: keep-alive\r\n'
b'<img src=3n6wo:3n6wo width="400" height="300"/>'

Cross site scripting vulnerability

MEDIUM

Summary

A Cross Site Scripting vulnerability was found at: "http://localhost/VulnerableApp/XSSInImgTagAttribute/LEVEL_4", using HTTP method GET. The sent data was: "src=a1twe%3Aa1twe" The modified parameter was "src". This vulnerability was found in the request with id 18667.


Description

Client-side scripts are used extensively by modern web applications. They perform from simple functions (such as the formatting of text) up to full manipulation of client-side data and Operating System interaction.

Cross Site Scripting (XSS) allows clients to inject arbitrary scripting code into a request and have the server return the script to the client in the response. This occurs because the application is taking untrusted data (in this example, from the client) and reusing it without performing any validation or encoding.

  • Vulnerable URL: http://localhost/VulnerableApp/XSSInImgTagAttribute/LEVEL_4
  • Vulnerable Parameter: src

Fix

To remedy XSS vulnerabilities, it is important to never use untrusted or unfiltered data within the code of a HTML page.

Untrusted data can originate not only form the client but potentially a third party or previously uploaded file etc. Filtering of untrusted data typically involves converting special characters to their HTML entity encoded counterparts (however, other methods do exist, see references). These special characters include:

  • &

  • >
  • "
  • '
  • /

  1. Directly in a script.
  2. Inside an HTML comment.
  3. In an attribute name.
  4. In a tag name.
  5. Directly in CSS.

  • Secunia

GET http://localhost/VulnerableApp/XSSInImgTagAttribute/LEVEL_4?src=a1twe%3Aa1twe HTTP/1.1
User-agent: python-requests/2.31.0
Host: localhost
Accept-encoding: gzip, deflate
Accept: */*
Connection: keep-alive
b'HTTP/1.1 200 \r\nServer: openresty/1.21.4.3\r\nDate: Wed, 20 Mar 2024 19:36:49 GMT\r\nContent-Type: text/plain;charset=UTF-8\r\nContent-Length: 47\r\nConnection: keep-alive\r\n'
b'<img src=a1twe:a1twe width="400" height="300"/>'

Blind SQL injection vulnerability

HIGH

Summary

Blind SQL injection was found at: "b'http://localhost/VulnerableApp/XSSInImgTagAttribute/LEVEL_3'", using HTTP method b'GET'. The injectable parameter is: "b'src'". This vulnerability was found in the requests with ids 19161 and 19226.


Description

Due to the requirement for dynamic content of today's web applications, many rely on a database backend to store data that will be called upon and processed by the web application (or other programs). Web applications retrieve data from the database by using Structured Query Language (SQL) queries.

To meet demands of many developers, database servers (such as MSSQL, MySQL, Oracle etc.) have additional built-in functionality that can allow extensive control of the database and interaction with the host operating system itself. An SQL injection occurs when a value originating from the client's request is used within a SQL query without prior sanitisation. This could allow cyber-criminals to execute arbitrary SQL code and steal data or use the additional functionality of the database server to take control of more server components.

The successful exploitation of a SQL injection can be devastating to an organisation and is one of the most commonly exploited web application vulnerabilities.

Injection was detected as it was possible to inject specific SQL queries, that if vulnerable, result in the responses for each injection being different. This is known as a blind SQL injection vulnerability.

  • Vulnerable URL: http://localhost/VulnerableApp/XSSInImgTagAttribute/LEVEL_3
  • Vulnerable Parameter: src

Fix

The only proven method to prevent against SQL injection attacks while still maintaining full application functionality is to use parameterized queries (also known as prepared statements). When utilising this method of querying the database, any value supplied by the client will be handled as a string value rather than part of the SQL query.

Additionally, when utilising parameterized queries, the database engine will automatically check to make sure the string being used matches that of the column. For example, the database engine will check that the user supplied input is an integer if the database column is configured to contain integers.

References

  • MITRE - CAPEC
  • WASC
  • W3 Schools
  • OWASP

HTTP proof

GET http://localhost/VulnerableApp/XSSInImgTagAttribute/LEVEL_3?src=44%27%20OR%20%2744%27%3D%2744%27%20OR%20%2744%27%3D%2744 HTTP/1.1
User-agent: python-requests/2.31.0
Host: localhost
Accept-encoding: gzip, deflate
Accept: */*
Connection: keep-alive
b'HTTP/1.1 200 \r\nServer: openresty/1.21.4.3\r\nDate: Wed, 20 Mar 2024 19:36:56 GMT\r\nContent-Type: text/plain;charset=UTF-8\r\nContent-Length: 104\r\nConnection: keep-alive\r\n'
b'<img src=26&quot; OR &quot;26&quot;=&quot;26&quot; OR &quot;26&quot;=&quot;26 width="400" height="300"/>'
GET http://localhost/VulnerableApp/XSSInImgTagAttribute/LEVEL_3?src=44%27%20OR%20%2744%27%3D%2744%27%20OR%20%2744%27%3D%2744 HTTP/1.1
User-agent: python-requests/2.31.0
Host: localhost
Accept-encoding: gzip, deflate
Accept: */*
Connection: keep-alive
b'HTTP/1.1 200 \r\nServer: openresty/1.21.4.3\r\nDate: Wed, 20 Mar 2024 19:36:56 GMT\r\nContent-Type: text/plain;charset=UTF-8\r\nContent-Length: 72\r\nConnection: keep-alive\r\n'
b'<img src=26&quot; AND &quot;26&quot;=&quot;27 width="400" height="300"/>'

Cross site scripting vulnerability

MEDIUM

Summary

A Cross Site Scripting vulnerability was found at: "http://localhost/VulnerableApp/XSSWithHtmlTagInjection/LEVEL_1", using HTTP method GET. The sent data was: "value=" The modified parameter was "value". This vulnerability was found in the request with id 19518.


Description

Cross Site Scripting (XSS) allows clients to inject arbitrary scripting code into a request and have the server return the script to the client in the response.   • Vulnerable URL: http://localhost/VulnerableApp/XSSWithHtmlTagInjection/LEVEL_1
  • Vulnerable Parameter: value

Fix

These special characters include:

  • &
  • <
  • >
  • "
  • '
  • /

An example of HTML entity encoding is converting < to &lt;. Although it is possible to filter untrusted input, there are five locations within an HTML page where untrusted input (even if it has been filtered) should never be placed:

  1. Directly in a script.
  2. Inside an HTML comment.
  3. In an attribute name.
  4. In a tag name.
  5. Directly in CSS.

  • Secunia
